<@U3E673SQL> thx
after git cloning and running `sudo make`
everything seems to work and it is running tests but then i get `behave: not found`
so behave seems to be a python programm for test ?
I don't know what default make does, I only did make peer
about the problem with GOPATH. I had to run `sudo make GOPATH= yourgopath`
so can someone tell me what is the difference between `sudo make` and `sudo make peer`
so running `sudo make behave` how many days does this take ^^
<@U3BSMKS21>: "make" is implicitly "make all" which if you look at the rule for "all" in the makefile, builds everything and runs all tests
whereas "make peer" will only build the native peer binary and anything that it depends on
it will not run any tests, and it will not build anything not strictly related to the peer
<@U0KPFAZNF> thx a lot so i understood that right. is it possible that after make all i have to set my PATH because the peer command does not work
i assume you are not in the vagrant environment?
if you are in vagrant, it should already have build/bin in the $PATH
if not, you'd have to manage this yourself

(fyi, things are still really structured around building/running from within vagrant...we will be improving the installability and generality of the development requirements moving forward, but we are not quite there yet
<@U0KPFAZNF>  yes im on ubuntu bare metal  and i included it in the PATH now. now when running `peer node start` i get CORE_PBFT unsupported config type
are you in mainline or v0.6?
ok, v0.6 is slightly more complicated because there are multiple configuration files
this was condensed in master to one file, which makes things slightly easier
but the problem is that the peer is looking for the configuration in ... (standby)
so basically would it be better to `rm -rf *` and git clone the master branch ?
well, it depends on what you want
v0.6 is stable, master is newer, more advanced, and still in development
so my intention is to learn a bit about chaincode and maybe write a very simple smart contract
@ghashkins thx a lot btw

<@U0KPFAZNF|ghaskins> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3FDEPZML/-.c|Untitled> and commented: This is an excerpt from a script I have that is setting up a v0.6 peer

file.name: -.c
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
cp $SRC/peer/core.yaml $DST/peer
cp $SRC/membersrvc/membersrvc.yaml $DST/membersrvc
cp $SRC/consensus/pbft/config.yaml $DST/consensus/pbft
cp $SRC/consensus/noops/config.yaml $DST/consensus/noops

initial_comment.comment: This is an excerpt from a script I have that is setting up a v0.6 peer

text: its not quite turnkey to solve the problem you are mentioning, but its related
in a nutshell, those are the files needed to spin up a v0.6 membersrvc/peer combo, and you will see that error if the peer cannot resolve them
usually, if you are running from a system with src installed, the easiest thing to do is ensure you run the peer with your $GOPATH set appropriately
this will auto-resolve to the configuration in the tree
otherwise, it ends up installing these in places like /etc/hyperledger/fabric
in this case, the error you are seeing is basically because its not finding consensus/pbft/config.yaml, which would have defined CORE_PBFT
thx a lot
np
i noticed that for some permission-denied reason i have to `sudo peer node start`
and typing `sudo go env` i see my GOPATH is not set
that might be the problem
yeah, that is your problem
if the GOPATH is set, those configuration files would be auto-resolved to the tree
thats wonderful :slightly_smiling_face:
you generally only need to muck around with the configuration files for when the binaries are installed without source
i am not sure why you need to launch the peer with sudo
its probably a peripheral issue (like the perms on the binary, or the perms on /var/hyperledger
maybe i have to chown something ?
yeah i think somewhere i have read that you have to chown /var/hyperledger/..
yes, that is def true
the ledger is written there
<@U36UDC6RK|kamo> has joined the channel
omg it is working :slightly_smiling_face:
cool
make sure to RECURSIVELY chown so:  `sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /var/hyperledger` did it
makes sense

in v0.6 we really don't officially support anything except vagrant builds
in master, we are pretty close to being able to build anywhere, or run from docker binaries in dockerhub
(this isnt to say it cant be done, its just a little more manual, as you have found)

Hello, im new here and i may have a stupid question.. How can i use the community docker membersrvc image with my own membersrvc,yaml ? (Regarding v0.6)

<@U36UDC6RK> I should point out first that despite the fact that docker images are published for v0.6, the support for running from anything but a source build is a little weak right now (see <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-678>).
that said, if you wanted to do this
I think you could effect the change you want by a) installing a new membersrvc.yaml file somewhere (say /etc/hyperledger/fabric) and then setting the WORKDIR to the same
because the v0.6 membersrvc will look for its config in the CWD
I _think_
heh
im reasonably confident this would work, but not 100%
(I should say this: I know it would look for its config in $CWD, but I am not sure which will take precedence)
alternatively, note that you can override any .yaml setting with envvars
fwiw, this is all much more straight forward in master: we map the configs to /etc/hyperledger/fabric in the container, so you could just override this dir with new config and its straight forward
v0.6 is still a little hacky, it has the full $GOPATH tree and pulls the config from that
First of all thank you for your immediate answer
overwriting the yaml settings with envvars is how i do it at the moment, but its not that userfriendly
ok, and I understand.  Just wanted to make sure you knew about that option since in most circumstances, that is easier
yes thank you, another question is: is there still a membersrvc.yaml in master?
long story short, i think you can do this in v0.6 but its going to be a little ugly
good point, membersrvc is gone in master
though this general approach is taken with the other containers
(at least for peer+orderer)
not sure what fabric-cop container looks like, as I didnt work on that one
long story short: v0.6 config override is a little ugly, master override is better supported
okay then i will try this approach, one last question: is the orderer taking the tasks of the membersrvc ? or what does the orderer do?
no, and I am certainly not an expert here: but my understanding is orderer is a teasing out of the peer consensus function, membersrvc is now in its own repo (and renamed to "COP")
so see fabric-cop.git
okay good, i understood it in the same way
so, ["peer" -> "peer + orderer", "membersrvc" -> "cop"] if you need a v0.6 -> master dictionary
okay nice!
